we because of the complexity of the site we had to do this in a phase migration approach so we put the the load
balancers and part of their application stack in AWS and then we were actually
passing traffic through the load balancers back to their physical data centers and we were slowly moving parts
of this application stack up behind the scenes so we they had a physical
load balancer in each location and they use these load balancers in a very very
very detailed fashion so they're not just load balancing passing traffic between
servers they're doing a ton of header rewrites they're load balancing UDP because they're running their own DNS
behind the scenes and for those reasons we couldn't just you know go ahead and use elastic load balancers they don't
support a lot of that functionality so we use the virtual edition of the physical load balancer that they had
deployed on-prem because we didn't want to go through and rewrite all the regex Expressions uh
we've soon realized that the virtual edition of the uh load balancer that

certainly unhappy this is semi-production and then if if those load balancers are going down and

scalers into their AWS environments thank you and uh I could quickly start
